etymologies: Old English geonian, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin hiare and Greek khainein. Current noun senses date from the early 18th century

definitions: involuntarily open one's mouth wide and inhale deeply due to tiredness or boredom

examples.text: he began yawning and looking at his watch

shortDefinitions: involuntarily open one's mouth wide and inhale deeply due to tiredness or boredom

definitions: (of an opening or space) be very large and wide

examples.text: she started inching back from the abyss that yawned before her
the whole empty day yawned before me

definitions: a reflex act of opening one's mouth wide and inhaling deeply due to tiredness or boredom

examples.text: he stretches and stifles a yawn

shortDefinitions: reflex act of opening one's mouth wide and inhaling deeply due to tiredness or boredom

definitions: a thing that is considered boring or tedious

examples.text: the awards show was a four-hour yawn

shortDefinitions: thing that is considered boring or tedious
